name.text: Born that way: Is there a gay gene and should it matter?
name.html: Born that way: Is there a gay gene and should it matter?

description.text:
An estimated 3 per cent of the population are lesbian or gay. Is it genetic – a biological 'accident of birth' predetermined in the womb – or could it be a choice? In other words, is sexual preference a social construction, or are we simply born that way? 
With the gay rights agenda still very much in the news, this question lies at the heart of the current debate. Join us as we explore these questions with our panel, chaired by Guardian writer Kira Cochrane and hear both sides of an issue that continues to polarise opinion. 
Panelists include: 
Julie Bindel, freelance journalist, feminist activist, co-founder of Justice for Women and author of controversial new book Straight Expectation. 
Qazi Rahman, academic at the Institute of Psychiatry King's College London, studying the biology of sexual orientation and the implications for mental health and author of the 2008 book, Born Gay. 
Patrick Strudwick, journalist, columnist, broadcaster and activist.  
Stella Duffy, award-winning novelist, theatre-maker and legendary gay rights campaigner. 
Kira Cochrane, journalist and features writer for The Guardian, focusing heavily on feminism and gender inequality issues in society today.

description.text:
Ian McEwan is one of the most celebrated British authors at work today. Join him to discuss his new novel The Children Act, which explores the conflict between science and religious conviction. His recent novels have tackled climate change (Solar) and cold war espoinage (Sweet Tooth). Inspired by real life legal cases, The Children Act centres on Fiona Mayes, a leading High Court judge who is called on to try an urgent case: 17 year old Adam who is refusing life-saving medical treatment because of his faith, with the support of his devout parents. McEwan will be in conversation with leading Guardian columnist and broadcasterJonathan Freedland. 
* Readers who select the ticket plus book option can collect their pre-ordered copy of the novel at the event. 
Vintage are offering readers a chance to win a signed first edition of The Children's Act and a selection of signed copies of some of Ian McEwan's best-loved novels. Click here for details. 
Concessions 
A limited allocation of concession tickets are available for ages under 18 and over 60.  Tickets are sold on first-come-first-served basis, and once sold, no further tickets are available by any method of booking. Appropriate cards to be show at event.

description.text:
Join David Mitchell for the UK launch event for his much-anticipated new novel The Bone Clocks. 
From the author of the genre-busting Cloud Atlas, this kaleidoscopic thriller looks ahead to life without oil. It tells the story of Holly Sykes in six segments, from her teenage years in 1980s Gravesend to her old age on the west coast of Ireland, raising her granddaughter while the world's climate collapses. The novel, a dazzling mix of realism and fantasy exploring the nature of mortality and survival, has been longlisted for this year’s Man Booker Prize. 
 
Mitchell's novels include number9dream, Ghostwritten and The Thousand Autumns of Jacob de Zoet. Cloud Atlas was shortlisted for the Man Booker Prize and adapted for the big screen in 2013. In 2003 he was selected as one of Granta's Best Young British Novelists. 
Chair: Claire Armitstead, books editor, Guardian News & Media and presenter, the Guardian books podcast 
* Readers who select the ticket plus book option can collect their pre-ordered copy of the novel at the event.

name.text: Weekend Magazine's Brunch with Yotam Ottolenghi
name.html: Weekend Magazine's Brunch with Yotam Ottolenghi

description.text:
This event has sold out. If you would like to attend join the waiting list and we will contact you if returns become available. 
Join Yotam Ottolenghi and guests for a two course brunch selected from his new recipe book, Plenty More. Picking up where Plenty left off, the book introduces a range of new vegetarian recipes, such as Alfonso mango and curried chickpea salad, Membrillo and stilton quiche and Candy beetroot with lentils. 
The Israeli-born chef and food writer will discuss his influences and the inspirations behind his new recipes with Weekend Magazine editor Melissa Denes. They will be joined by Alys Fowler, the Guardian's gardening columnist, and wine writer Fiona Beckett. 
A standard ticket is £50 and includes a two-course brunch.  A ticket with a pre-ordered copy of the book is £66 (and includes a free Ottolenghi tote bag). 
*Readers who select the ticket plus book option can collect their pre-ordered copy of Plenty More at the event. 
Concessions 
A limited allocation of concession tickets are available for ages under 18 and over 60.  Tickets are sold on first-come-first-served basis, and once sold, no further tickets are available by any method of booking. Appropriate cards to be show at event.

description.text:
A BBC sports presenter since 1998, Clare Balding is one of our best loved broadcasters. For over twelve years she has hiked across the British countryside for her Radio 4 show, Rambling. Now in, Walking Home: My Family and Other Rambles, she recounts a journey with her brother across the 71 mile long Wayfarer's Walk. In her sequel to the number one bestseller My Animals and Other Family, she discusses apocalyptic thunderstorms, stripping off in bus stops, battling with blisters and her experience of the 2012 Olympics. At an evening hosted by the Guardian she will share her enthusiasm for the great outdoors, and the paths, people and places she has encountered along the way. 
* Readers who select the ticket plus book option can collect their pre-ordered copy of Walking Home at the event. 
 Concessions 
A limited allocation of concession tickets are available for ages under 18 and over 60.  Tickets are sold on first-come-first-served basis, and once sold, no further tickets are available by any method of booking. Appropriate cards to be show at event.

name.text: Hatreds Old And New: Jonathan Freedland and Mehdi Hasan discuss anti-Semitism and Islamophobia
name.html: Hatreds Old And New: Jonathan Freedland and Mehdi Hasan discuss anti-Semitism and Islamophobia

description.text:
Jonathan Freedland and Mehdi Hasan debate anti-Semitism and Islamophobia, chaired by Anita Anand.  After the recent conflict in Gaza, anti-Semitism and Islamophobia are on the rise. Meanwhile, Jews and Muslims in Britain find themselves at odds with each other, their relationship once again held hostage to events in the Middle East. But does it have to be this way? Where do these two communities stand on the role of faith in the public sphere, on the persistence of prejudice and the record of their own leaders? Are there internal conversations these two communities are having that outsiders rarely hear, conversations which Jews and Muslims might begin to have with each other and the rest of British society. 
The Guardian and The Huffington Post UK bring together two of Britain's leading commentators – Jonathan Freedland, who is Jewish, and Mehdi Hasan, who is Muslim – to debate ancient hatreds, modern prejudices and the rise of identity politics, chaired by journalist and broadcaster, Anita Anand. 
Concessions 
A limited allocation of concession tickets are available for ages under 18 and over 60.  Tickets are sold on first-come-first-served basis, and once sold, no further tickets are available by any method of booking. Appropriate cards to be show at event.

Join us for the first in a behind-the-scenes series of events where we welcome members into the Guardian offices, and discuss with the editorial team how they shape the headlines of tomorrow based on the events of the day. 
 
Guardian journalists including columnists Polly Toynbee and Deborah Orr, and economics correspondent Phillip Inman, will review the reaction to the results of Thursday’s referendum, take your questions and look ahead to the following day’s paper.
 
Ticket price includes a drink on arrival. There will be a chance to continue the conversation with fellow members in the Guardian offices afterwards.

 
Concessions

description.text:
In How to Speak Money, John Lanchester, author of Whoops! andCapital, aims to decode the complex, jargon-filled language of money. From high-frequency trading to collateral debt obligations, from amortization to Greater Fool theory, this witty and entertaining account explains the language of finance, how it can often mislead, and why it's so important for us to understand it. He will be in conversation with the Guardian's economics editor, Larry Elliott. 
* Readers who select the ticket plus book option can collect their pre-ordered copy of How To Speak Money at the event. 
  
Concessions 
A limited allocation of concession tickets are available for ages under 18 and over 60.  Tickets are sold on first-come-first-served basis, and once sold, no further tickets are available by any method of booking. Appropriate cards to be shown at event.

description.text:
Join the Guardian Guide for brunch at Dalston's new neighbourhood restaurant Rotorino. 
Tickets include a southern Italian menu from chef Stevie Parle (formerly of River Cafe) along with a cocktail, newspapers and coffee. Plus editor Paul MacInnes will talk to Joe Goddard (Hot Chip) and Raf Rundell about their new album as The 2 Bears and how London shaped their music. Comedy comes from award winning comedian Josie Long fresh from her Edinburgh Festival sell out show. 
Fed, watered, entertained. It's what brunch was invented for. 
Rotorino is a new neighbourhood Italian restaurant and wine bar. They cook simple southern Italian food with one foot firmly in Dalston. The main focus is on delicious antipasti, fresh pasta and top notch British meat and fish grilled over wood.

description.text:
The Premier League's TV deal is worth £5bn. The first £100m transfer fee is fast approaching. The most expensive season tickets cost almost £2000. Football and footballers have never been richer but is this extraordianary growth sustainable, and what about the game's suffering grass roots? Join Guardian sports writer David Conn and a panel of leading industry experts for an evening of discussion on the finances of football past, present and future. 
  
Panellists include:  
  
David Conn, sports writer, the Guardian (Chair) 
  
Robin Osterley, chief executive, Supporters Direct 
  
Heather Rabbatts, director, FA 
  
Owen Gibson, chief sports correspondent, the Guardian

name.text: A Life in Music: Spandau Ballet's Gary Kemp
name.html: A Life in Music: Spandau Ballet's Gary Kemp

description.text:
Gary Kemp of Spandau Ballet talks to the Guardian's Alexis Petridis about the band's extraordinary career. One of the defining bands of the 80's, with over 25 million albums, Spandau lasted ten years; a career that spanned the nightclubs of Soho to Hollywood and stadiums around the world. 
 
Join us for a live interview followed by a screening of the band’s new feature length documentary Soulboys Of The Western World.
 
Concessions 
A limited allocation of concession tickets are available for ages under 21 and over 60. Tickets are sold on first-come-first-served basis, and once sold, no further tickets are available by any method of booking. Appropriate cards to be shown at event.

description.text:
This October the Guardian will host two events with the bestselling author to celebrate the publication of his new book, Us. 
From the author of the much-loved novel One Day, Us is the story of Douglas Petersen, whose son, Albie, is about to leave for college, and whose wife of 21 years, Connie, is planning to leave soon afterwards. But first there will be the summer holiday - a Grand Tour of Europe's major cities - during which Douglas devises a plan to win back the love of his wife and repair his troubled relationship with his son. The novel, a bittersweet comedy about the demands of parenthood and living together, has been longlisted for this year's Man Booker Prize.  
Manchester 
Wednesday 1 October, 6.30pm 
The Cornerhouse, 70 Oxford Street, Manchester, M1 5NH 
Book tickets 
  
Edinburgh 
Thursday 2 October, 7.30pm 
Waterstones, 128 Princes Street, Edinburgh, EH2 4AD

description.text:
Naomi Klein, the award-winning journalist and author of global best-sellers The Shock Doctrine and No Logo discusses her most provocative book yet, This Changes Everything: Capitalism vs the Climate. Klein challenges the myths that cloud the climate debate, refutes the argument for dependence on fossil fuels and aims to show how our current economic model is waging and winning a war on earth. 
In conversation with columnist and writer Owen Jones, Klein will discuss why she believes climate change is a wake-up call for civilisation, why it's now about changing the world and not just lightbulbs and how tearing up the "free-market" playbook may be the answer. 
This Changes Everything will be published by Allen Lane.You can purchase a copy of the book with your ticket for a special discount price of £11.50 (RRP £20). Select the book as an additional item on the ticket order form. Your copy of the book will be available for collection at the event.Readers who select the ticket plus book option can collect their pre-ordered copy of the book at the event. 
* Readers who select the ticket plus book option can collect their pre-ordered copy of How To Speak Money at the event. 
Concessions 
A limited allocation of concession tickets are available for ages under 18 and over 60.  Tickets are sold on first-come-first-served basis, and once sold, no further tickets are available by any method of booking. Appropriate cards to be shown at event. 
 
Please note tickets for this event must be pre-purchased. Tickets will not be available to purchase at the event and non-ticket holders will not be admitted entry. Ticket sales will close at 10am on Monday 6 October and after this time no further tickets will be available.

description.text:
Observer Ideas is a one day festival of talks, debates and performances with a variety of speakers including: scientists, mathematicians, chefs, campaigners, musicians and environmentalists. With live music throughout the day and subjects ranging from technology to art, from science to food, and from big data to the economy this is a festival of the mind designed to inspire, challenge and maybe even provoke. 
The festival, supported by BT will feature David Simon, creator of the acclaimed TV series The Wire. Other speakers include Tinie Tempah, Conchita Wurst, Jeremy Deller, Rokia Traore, Jack Monroe and Evgeny Morozov 
To give you an idea of the breadth of topics to be discussed here is an outline of who is coming, and what they will talk about. 
  
Edward Snowden 
FEW individuals change the world. There is no doubt that the world, and what we know about the way our world operates, changed fundamentally on June 5, 2013.  
That was the day the Guardian published the former intelligence analyst's explosive leaks and our understanding of data, government, and privacy changed forever. The documents that Snowden gathered and that the Guardian published showed how numerous global surveillance programmes gather our digital data, without our consent, and with barely any democratic oversight.  
It has fuelled an urgent worldwide debate that shows no sign of resolution. And whatever the impact, politically, there is no doubt that it was undertaken at great personal expense. Nine days after the first publication, the US Department of Justice charged Snowden with two counts of violating the Espionage Act and theft of government property, punishable by up to 30 years in prison. His passport was revoked and he has been stranded in Russia ever since. 
His appearance at Observer Ideas is the first time he has spoken, live, to a British audience since the story broke.  
David Simon , author, journalist, TV writer/director/producer 
The New Americas  
David Simon, the most acclaimed and feted TV creator in the United States (winning multiple Emmys for Homicide, The Wire and Treme and currently working on a HBO mini-series about race in America based on Lisa Belkin's non-fiction book, Show Me A Hero) will tell us what he learned about his country during the writing and making of award-winning TV series.   
  
Tinie Tempah, musician, entrepreneur 
My life in music 
Tinie has talked eloquently in the past about about the importance of family and role models, and the role that music can play in engaging with young adolescents. He will reflect on his own upbringing in London, his emergence as one of the most prominent faces in British music and his move from musician to running a business and building a brand. 
  
Maggie Aderin-Pocock, space scientist, presenter of the BBC's The Sky at Night 
Why all children should be taught to reach for the stars  
Maggie will deliver a highly-personal talk about growing up as a dyslexic child of African immigrants in London – and how she overcame many challenges to become the UK's foremost space scientist and new face of astronomy on the BBC.   
  
Cedric Villani, mathematician, author  
The art and romance of mathematics  
Cedric Villani is one of the world's leading mathematicians – winner of the Fields Medal (often called the Nobel Prize for Maths) and one of just 52 mathematicians to have received it. 
  
Conchita Wurst, musician, campaigner 
Rise Like a Phoenix 
Conchita Wurst won the Eurovision Song Contest for Austria this year. Her appearance caused a furore when a vocal minority protested at what they saw as a performance which promoted LGBT rights. Wurst responded: "It was not just a victory for me but a victory for those people who believe in a future that can function without discrimination." Conchita will talk about the impact of her performance and the reaction to it, and will then perform Rise Like A Phoenix. 
  
Jeremy Deller , Turner-award winning artist  
The story of Adrian Street  
When Jeremy Deller bought an album by the band Black Box Recorder many years ago he was struck by the picture on the cover. Jeremy set out to track down the person in the photograph. This is the story of what happened next.   
  
Kim Dotcom , entrepreneur, pirate, digital activist, ex-playboy  
Q&A: My life as a digital revolutionary 
Founder of Megaupload one of the biggest sharing sites in the world, but arrested by New Zealand police a year ago acting on a warrant from the FBI. He is fighting extradition, has started a political party in New Zealand and has galvanised a group of digital activists to campaign against mass surveillance   
  
Jack Monroe, food writer, campaigner 
The politics of food 
As a single mother to a young son, Jack was forced to give up her job working for the Essex fire service when she couldn't find childcare to cover her nightshifts. Living on benefits, she learned the hard way how to cook on a budget. She started a blog, A Girl Called Jack and now writes a weekly column for the Guardian. Her second book is coming out this Autumn. 
  
Rokia Traore, musician, campaigner 
The story of African women 
Rokia, an award winning singer, songwriter and guitarist from Mali, is one of the most identifiable figures in African music. Rokia will speak and also perform a couple of songs to illustrate her story of African women. Last year, she explained the final track, Sarama, on her recent album Beautiful Arica: "These women are simply amazing. They are like iron women.” 
  
Edwyn Collins, musician 
The Possibilities Are Endless 
The Possibilities Are Endless is the title of a new film about the singer Edwyn Collins who suffered a stroke in 2005. The film premieres at the London Film Festival the day before Observer Ideas. Edwyn and his wife Grace will talk about the impact of losing your memory, your speech and very nearly your mind. The title of the film refers to one of the few phrases that Edwyn could recall after his stroke. Edwyn will also perform a song or two. 
  
Benjamin Clementine , musician  
Words and Music  
Benjamin Clementine was born and raised in London before moving to Paris in his early twenties. His first EP, Cornerstone, was released in June 2013. Though a musician, he also considers himself a writer. He told The Observer recently: "I don't think I'm a singer, I think I'm an expressionist. Having a spell in France, they put a lot of detail into the lyrics, it's very important because everyone is listening to what they are saying. It's like a play. 
  
Chido Govera, educator, farmer, campaigner 
How mushrooms can help save young African women  
Chido will speak about the work she does across Africa and Asia and how the farming of mushrooms – itself a very simple process – had helped deliver independence, self-respect and money to thousands of young women.   
  
Anthony Zaborski, cyber security expert 
How safe is your ‘smart’ phone? 
Anthony Zaborski has worked as a cyber-security expert for nearly 20 years and before that was a hacker of international renown. On stage he will reveal to the audience just how unsafe their phones are, and will show us the electronic secrets we  leave behind. 
  
Dr Kate Stone , Cambridge scientist, start-up entrepreneur  
Come and play my DJ decks... they're made of paper  
"I love paper, and I love technology," says physicist and former sheep herder Kate Stone, who's spent the past decade working to unite the two. She will demonstrate the innovative result live ion stage.  
  
Denai Moore, musician 
Words and music  
Born in Spanish Town Jamaica, Denai was surrounded by music from a young age. Aged 10 Moore relocated with her family to Stratford, East London. One of Britain's brightest young talents and tipped by TimeOut among others for stardom she will perform a small number of songs and talk about her musical influences. 
  
Evgeny Morozov, acclaimed author of The Net Delusion, and academic 
Does Silicon Valley have all the answers? 
Evgeny Morozov will talk about Silicon Valley and its growing belief that technology can provide an answer for all of the world's problems. Morozov will talk about why he has become a sceptic amongst a community of enthusiasts.  
  
Michael Twitty , culinary historian, chef  
What happened to the history of Deep South Cooking? 
Author and chef Michael will talk through the history of African-American cooking and why it has been written out of the history of the landmark of American cuisines – the food of the Deep South. 
  
Body & Soul 
Words and music 
Body & Soul is a multi-award-winning charity based in London that looks after children and families affected by HIV. This year Body & Soul celebrates its 18th year. Members of the Body & Soul choir will talk and sing about their experiences. 
  
The Observer, the world's oldest Sunday newspaper, has a proud history of spreading ideas, encouraging debate and campaigning vigorously across a range of issues. This event is in the spirit of that tradition. 
  
Concessions 
A limited allocation of concession tickets are available for ages under 18 and over 60. Tickets are sold on first-come-first-served basis, and once sold, no further tickets are available by any method of booking. Appropriate cards to be shown at event.

Observer Ideas is a one day festival of talks, debates and performances with a variety of speakers including: scientists, mathematicians, chefs, campaigners, musicians and environmentalists. With live music throughout the day and subjects ranging from technology to art, from science to food, and from big data to the economy this is a festival of the mind designed to inspire, challenge and maybe even provoke.

The festival, supported by BT will feature David Simon, creator of the acclaimed TV series The Wire. Other speakers include Tinie Tempah, Conchita Wurst, Jeremy Deller, Rokia Traore, Jack Monroe and Evgeny Morozov

To give you an idea of the breadth of topics to be discussed here is an outline of who is coming, and what they will talk about.


Edward Snowden

FEW individuals change the world. There is no doubt that the world, and what we know about the way our world operates, changed fundamentally on June 5, 2013. 

That was the day the Guardian published the former intelligence analyst's explosive leaks and our understanding of data, government, and privacy changed forever. The documents that Snowden gathered and that the Guardian published showed how numerous global surveillance programmes gather our digital data, without our consent, and with barely any democratic oversight. 

It has fuelled an urgent worldwide debate that shows no sign of resolution. And whatever the impact, politically, there is no doubt that it was undertaken at great personal expense. Nine days after the first publication, the US Department of Justice charged Snowden with two counts of violating the Espionage Act and theft of government property, punishable by up to 30 years in prison. His passport was revoked and he has been stranded in Russia ever since.

His appearance at Observer Ideas is the first time he has spoken, live, to a British audience since the story broke. 

David Simon , author, journalist, TV writer/director/producer

The New Americas 

David Simon, the most acclaimed and feted TV creator in the United States (winning multiple Emmys for Homicide, The Wire and Treme and currently working on a HBO mini-series about race in America based on Lisa Belkin's non-fiction book, Show Me A Hero) will tell us what he learned about his country during the writing and making of award-winning TV series.  

 

Tinie Tempah, musician, entrepreneur

My life in music

Tinie has talked eloquently in the past about about the importance of family and role models, and the role that music can play in engaging with young adolescents. He will reflect on his own upbringing in London, his emergence as one of the most prominent faces in British music and his move from musician to running a business and building a brand.

 

Maggie Aderin-Pocock, space scientist, presenter of the BBC's The Sky at Night

Why all children should be taught to reach for the stars 

Maggie will deliver a highly-personal talk about growing up as a dyslexic child of African immigrants in London – and how she overcame many challenges to become the UK's foremost space scientist and new face of astronomy on the BBC.

description.text:
Shami Chakrabarti joined Liberty the day before the 9/11 attacks. As the political climate shifted, and governments talked of a war on terror, many commentators became alarmed that civil rights were in danger of being eroded in the name of national security. 
In her new book, On Liberty, Chakrabarti draws on her work on high profile campaigns - including those against ID cards, 42-day detention and imprisonment of foreign terror suspects without trial - to highlight the threats to our democratic institutions and why our fundamental freedoms are essential to our democracy. She will be in conversation with Guardian columnist Zoe Williams. 
* You can purchase a copy of On Liberty with your ticket for a special discount price of £11 (RRP £17.99). Select the book as an additional item on the ticket order form. Your copy of the book can be collected at the event.  
Concessions 
A limited allocation of concession tickets are available for ages under 18 and over 60. Tickets are sold on first-come-first-served basis, and once sold, no further tickets are available by any method of booking. Appropriate cards to be shown at event

description.text:
In a rare live interview Jimmy Page, founder member, guitarist and producer of Led Zeppelin, will discuss his extraordinary life and career with Guardian Music Editor, Michael Hann.   As he releases his photographic autobiography ‘Jimmy Page’ – the first book by a member of Led Zeppelin – the interview will explore the life of a man both on and off stage, accompanied by a selection of personally selected photographs from the book.* 
* You can purchase a copy of the book with your ticket for a special discount price of £30 (RRP £40). Select the book as an additional item on the order form. Books purchased with a ticket will be available for collection on the night. These books will have been personally authenticated by Jimmy, with his logo, the date and city, making them exclusive to this event.

description.text:
Vivienne Westwood, one our most celebrated and influential fashion designers, will talk to Guardian columnist Deborah Orr about her long and legendary career. This autumn, for the first time, she will publish her memoir, co-written with Ian Kelly and featuring contributions from friends including Deborah Harry, Tracey Emin and the Prince of Wales. At a special Guardian Live event she will share stories from her life and career: from her first shop on the Kings Road with Malcolm Maclaren, to the Sex Pistols and the birth of punk, to receiving her OBE and her activism for Greenpeace and Liberty. Join us for a very special evening as we explore the life and work of a British icon. 
You can purchase a copy of the book with your ticket for a special discount price of £20 (RRP £25). Select the book as an additional item on the ticket order form. Your copy of the book can be collected at the event.  
Concessions 
A limited allocation of concession tickets are available for ages under 21 and over 60.  Tickets are sold on first-come-first-served basis, and once sold, no further tickets are available by any method of booking. Appropriate cards to be shown at event.

description.text:
Does the Guardian discriminate against men in its columns? Should the Guardian have accepted the This World advertisement about the conflict in Gaza? Should Guardian journalists use the term "illegal immigrant"?
 



These are just a few of the questions the Guardian readers' editor has faced when dealing with the 27,000 complaints and queries he and his colleagues receive each year. 
 
What is the role of the Guardian readers' editor? "To collect, consider, investigate, respond to, and where appropriate come to a conclusion about readers' comments, concerns, and complaints in a prompt and timely manner, from a position of independence within the paper."



 
That's the official description of the responsibility of the Guardian readers' editor, the role of internal ombudsman that was introduced in 1997. Since then, only three people have done the job, the latest being Chris Elliott. 
 
A journalist for more 40 years, Chris has worked in Fleet Street for 31 of them. He's been a reporter and news editor on the Times, the Sunday Telegraph and the Sunday Correspondent. More recently he was managing editor of Guardian News & Media, an organisation Chris has been with for 19 years. 
 

Join Chris and his colleagues to discuss these questions and more at the Guardian offices on Thursday 16 October. He and his colleagues will talk about the history of the readers' editor role in the UK and elsewhere, describe its responsibilities and talk guests through an average working week. The event will include a Q&A session.

name.text: Guardian Live event, Manchester: the science of cycling
name.html: Guardian Live event, Manchester: the science of cycling

description.text:
Join some of the most esteemed and experienced cycling experts in the world as they offer advice and information on the pursuit for cycling perfection. Chaired by the Guardian's cycling correspondent William Fotheringham, the discussions will feature tips and advice from Olympic medallist Emma Pooley and top coaches from British Cycling, giving the perfect opportunity for cyclists of all levels to tap into the expertise which has won a raft of Olympic medals and world championships. 
National Cycling Centre was Britain's first indoor Olympic cycling track and remains one of the busiest in the world with regular users from elite athletes to local enthusiasts. Join us at the home of British Cycling and find out how to take your performance up that extra gear. 
Panellists include: Will Fotheringham, cycling correspondent, the Guardian 
Emma Pooley, former professional cyclist and Olympic medallist 
Tony Purnell, head of technical development, Great Britain Cycling Team 
Phil Burt, lead physiotherapist, British Cycling 
  
Concessions

description.text:
Russell Brand, one of Britain’s most controversial public figures, will be in conversation with Guardian columnist and political writer, Owen Jones at the Emmanuel Centre in London. In his new book, Revolution, Brand argues that the system isn’t working, that our governments are corrupt and the opposing parties are all pointlessly similar. Is there another way or is this just ‘the way things are’? Brand has been taking on Morning talk show hosts, Fox News fascists and BBC stalwarts and now, drawing on the likes of Orwell and Piketty, sets out his ideas for a brighter, fairer society.
 
Please note ticket sales for this event will close at 08.00am on Thursday 23 October. 
 

You can purchase a copy of the book with your ticket for a special discount price of £12 (RRP £20). Select the book as an additional item on the ticket order form. Your copy of the book can be collected at the event.

description.text:
For the first time, in partnership with Picturehouse Cinemas, Russell Brand’s Guardian Live event will be broadcast live via satellite to over 200 cinemas around the UK. Audiences around the country will be able to watch the talk and join in the debate online and via Twitter. 
In his new book Revolution, Brand argues that the system isn’t working, that our governments are corrupt and the opposing parties are all pointlessly similar. Is there another way or is this just ‘the way things are’? 
For years, Brand has been taking on talk show hosts, Fox News fascists and BBC stalwarts and now, drawing on the likes of Orwell and Piketty, the comedian sets out his ideas for a brighter, fairer society. At this exclusive Guardian Live event, Brand will explain why he thinks revolution isn’t just possible, but inevitable. 
You can watch it broadcast live to cinemas across the UK. Simply click on your nearest participating cinema from the list below to purchase your ticket.

description.html:
For the first time, in partnership with Picturehouse Cinemas, Russell Brand’s Guardian Live event will be broadcast live via satellite to over 200 cinemas around the UK. Audiences around the country will be able to watch the talk and join in the debate online and via Twitter.

In his new book Revolution, Brand argues that the system isn’t working, that our governments are corrupt and the opposing parties are all pointlessly similar. Is there another way or is this just ‘the way things are’?

For years, Brand has been taking on talk show hosts, Fox News fascists and BBC stalwarts and now, drawing on the likes of Orwell and Piketty, the comedian sets out his ideas for a brighter, fairer society. At this exclusive Guardian Live event, Brand will explain why he thinks revolution isn’t just possible, but inevitable.

You can watch it broadcast live to cinemas across the UK. Simply click on your nearest participating cinema from the list below to purchase your ticket.

description.text:
The master of LA noir will talk to John Mullan about corrupt cops, femme fatales and his classic crime novel The Black Dahlia. 
When a wannabe starlet is found brutally murdered in a vacant field in Los Angeles, the story make headlines and sparks the biggest manhunt in California history. The plot centres on two cops, Bucky and Lee, who become increasingly obsessed with the case as their investigation uncovers the corruptions of postwar Hollywood. 
The Black Dahlia is the first of the LA Quartet series of novels, which includes LA Confidential and The Big Nowhere. Ellroy is currently working on a second LA Quartet, set during the second world war. The first book, Perfidia, will be published in September 2014. 
Concessions 
A limited allocation of concession tickets are available for ages under 18 and over 60. Tickets are sold on first-come-first-served basis, and once sold, no further tickets are available by any method of booking. Appropriate cards to be shown at event

name.text: Guardian Newsroom: the rise of Ukip
name.html: Guardian Newsroom: the rise of Ukip

description.text:
Ahead of the Rochester by-election we consider the rise of Ukip: how did they get here and how far can they go?  
Join us at the Guardian offices as we discuss the party, their policies and their potential impact on the elections. Head of news Stuart Millar chairs the event, joined by writers and columnists across the news and comment desks, including columnist Simon Jenkins; foreign affairs commentator Natalie Nougayrede; political correspondent Rowena Mason; and diary editor Hugh Muir. Our panel also takes a look at the next day's paper, with an insight into how the news of the day shapes the headlines of tomorrow.  
We have a space reserved in the Kings Place bar  from 8pm afterwards for those who wish to carry on the conversation with journalists and meet other members.  
To get a taste of our unique Newsroom events inviting our members into editorial discussions, take a look at last month's event chaired by editor Alan Rusbridger, dissecting the reaction to the Scottish referendum result as it happened.

description.text:
Guardian Film Club is a chance to hear some of today’s filmmakers talk about their work, the films that have influenced them and to revisit a classic of modern cinema.  Each guest curates a film of their choice and takes part in a Q&A hosted by one of our Film team, followed by a screening of the film.  
  
First up: Richard Ayoade will introduce Francois Truffaut’s Day for Night. The comedian and actor, best known for his role in the IT Crowd, has directed music videos for bands including the Arctic Monkeys and Vampire Weekend. His first film, Submarine, was a  stylish adaptation of Joe Dunthorne’s coming-of-age novel. The Double, released this year, is an unsettling, absurdist comedy about a meek office worker who meets his doppelganger, inspired by a Dostoyevsky story.  
  
He will talk to Guardian film critic Peter Bradshaw about Francois Truffaut’s 1973 classic, Day for Night, a film about filmmaking. Truffaut himself plays the harassed director making a melodrama called Meet Pamela on location in Nice. As the production descends into chaos it is his job to keep the drama of real life off-screen (affairs, accidents, imbroglios, death..). A gentle, funny tribute to the movie business and the magic of cinema, the film won the 1973 Best Oscar for a Foreign Film. Watch out for a cameo appearance by Graham Greene. 
  
This October, Faber will publish Ayoade on Ayoade: a cinematic odyssey, in which the director reflects on his great cinematic legacy as only he can: in conversation with himself. You can buy a copy of the book at a special discount of £12 when you purchase your ticket. Select the book as an additional item on the ticket order form. Your copy of the book can be collected at the event.  
  



Concessions 
A limited allocation of concession tickets are available for ages under 21 and over 60.  Tickets are sold on first-come-first-served basis, and once sold, no further tickets are available by any method of booking. Appropriate cards to be shown at event.

name.text: Guardian Live event: knowledge is beautiful with David McCandless
name.html: Guardian Live event: knowledge is beautiful with David McCandless

description.text:
Every minute of every day we are bombarded with information. But how can we relate to this data overload? David McCandless is a data journalist and designer, and author of the bestselling Information is Beautiful. From national military budgets, to bird flu outbreaks andDoctor Who's journeys through time, his elegant infographics bring to life information too complex or abstract to grasp any way but visually. 
In his new book, Knowledge is Beautiful, covering everything from dog breeds and movie plots to most commonly used passwords, his designs highlight connections and contexts to make information meaningful, and entertaining. 
At an event hosted by the Guardian he will present and explain some of his new infographic designs. He will be in conversation with co-founder of Decoded, Alasdair Blackwell, at Level 39, on the 39th floor of the iconic One Canada Square building in Canary Wharf. 
Concessions 
A limited allocation of concession tickets are available for ages under 18 and over 60.  Tickets are sold on first-come-first-served basis, and once sold, no further tickets are available by any method of booking. Appropriate cards to be shown at event.

description.text:
Join the bestselling author for a discussion of his new novel, Funny Girl. Set in the 1960s, it follows Sophie Straw, a young woman who goes from Blackpool beauty queen to fame on a greater scale as the star of a hugely popular sitcom. The novel returns to some of the themes Hornby explored in earlier novels: popular culture, youth and old age, class and celebrity. At a reading earlier this year he said that it was an attempt "to rewrite history and create a British Lucille Ball". 
 Nick Hornby’s novels include High Fidelity, About A Boy and A Long Way Down, all of which have been into major films. He has also written screenplays for the Oscar-nominate An  Education and the forthcoming adaptation of Colm Toibin’s Brooklyn. 

 
 

You can purchase a copy of the book with your ticket for a special discount price of £12 (RRP £20). Select the book as an additional item on the ticket order form. Your copy of the book can be collected at the event.

description.text:
David Mitchell will discuss his new book Thinking About It Only Makes It Worse. 
Why is my jumper depreciating? Why is every film a sequel or a remake? Is there anything to be done about the internet? Thinking About It Only Makes It Worse - drawn from Observer columns and including new material - explores these troubling questions and other absurdities of modern life. 
David Mitchell is a BAFTA winning comedian, actor and writer and the polysyllabic member of Mitchell and Webb. He writes for the Observer, chairs The Unbelievable Truth, co-hosts 10 O'Clock Live, is a team captain on Would I Lie To You? and has been in two films, neither of which made a profit. 
You can purchase a copy of the book with your ticket for a special discount price of £10 (RRP £18.99). Select the book as an additional item on the ticket order form. Your copy of the book can be collected at the event.  
Concessions 
A limited allocation of concession tickets are available for ages under 18 and over 60.  Tickets are sold on first-come-first-served basis, and once sold, no further tickets are available by any method of booking. Appropriate cards to be shown at event.

name.text: Guardian Live event: Pussy Riot - art, sex and revolution
name.html: Guardian Live event: Pussy Riot - art, sex and revolution

description.text: Imprisoned by Putin, horsewhipped in Sochi and hounded by the secret services.   Pussy Riot, came to prominence in 2012 when the imprisonment of three of their members caused global outrage. After 18 months Nadya and Masha emerged to find a Russia more in Putin’s control than ever. At their first ever UK event, they talk to Luke Harding about their time in prison, campaigns for women's rights, political freedom and reform of the justice system and how they became a thorn in the side of one of the world’s most powerful men.

name.html: Guardian Live event - a life in politics: Ken Clarke

description.text: Michael White has interviewed and written about Ken Clarke for almost 40 years. As one of the last of the political 'big beasts' begins to step back from public life, Michael talks to the former chancellor of the exchequer, justice secretary and home secretary about his career in politics, his thoughts on the future of Britain in Europe and the controversial Tory plans for the European Court of Human Rights.

name.text: Guardian Review Book Club: William Gibson
name.html: Guardian Review Book Club: William Gibson

description.text: Join us for a Guardian Review Book Club with novelist William Gibson, to celebrate the 30th anniversary of the publication of his cyberpunk classic, Neuromancer. A fast-paced thriller starring Case, a washed up hacker, a cybernetically enhanced mercenary called Molly Millions, and a powerful artificial intelligence known as The Matrix, the novel was Gibson’s debut and won the Hugo, Nebula and Philip K Dick awards. Anticipating the internet, the novel popularised the term “cyberspace” - a "consensual hallucination" created by millions of connected computers - and influenced a raft of films and novels, including The Wachowski Brothers’ Matrix trilogy and Christopher Nolan’s Inception. Gibson will be in conversation with John Mullan, Head of Engish at UCL and host of the Guardian’s Book Club.

description.text:
When Canadian astronaut Chris Hadfield performed a zero gravity cover of David Bowie's Space Oddity from the International Space Station in 2013 he became a household name. His chronicling of life in space earned him a devoted following on twitter and facebook around the world. 
In his new book, You are Here, he has collected the best of his photographs of Earth from space. At events in London and Bristol hosted by the Guardian he will show some of these breathtaking images on a big screen and share a few stories from his life in orbit. He might even bring his guitar... 
Concessions

When Canadian astronaut Chris Hadfield performed a zero gravity cover of David Bowie's Space Oddity from the International Space Station in 2013 he became a household name. His chronicling of life in space earned him a devoted following on twitter and facebook around the world. 
In his new book, You are Here, he has collected the best of his photographs of Earth from space. At events in London and Bristol hosted by the Guardian he will show some of these breathtaking images on a big screen and share a few stories from his life in orbit. He might even bring his guitar...

name.text: Guardian Live event: is Cameron more radical than Thatcher?
name.html: Guardian Live event: is Cameron more radical than Thatcher?

description.text:
In their new book Cameron's Coup Polly Toynbee and David Walker argue that Cameron is turning out to be more radical than Thatcher. In conversation with columnist and broadcaster Steve Richards, they will explain why they think the cuts are cover for an assault on the post-war social settlement and the government is creating a harsher, meaner Britain.

Don't forget to add a copy of the book to your order on the next page
